In fact, emojis have become so popular that the Oxford dictionary listed ğŸ˜‚ as the word of 2015. Nowadays, emojis are ubiquitous, appearing on virtually every digital platform, including Tiktok, Instagram , or email . Many people even choose to incorporate emojis into their usernames. Emojis also make their presence in areas outside of social media: there was an estimated 25,000 registered emoji domains in 2018, and an Artificial Intelligence startup huggingface ğŸ¤— will potentially be the first company to â€œgo public with an emoji, rather than a three-letter tickerâ€.

Given the popularity of emojis, it is not hard to envision that one day in the courtroom, judges will have to examine evidence in the form of emojis, and someone will be fined or sent to jail for sending certain emojis. Okay, it has already happened in both civil and criminal cases worldwide. And let me tell you this: although itâ€™s funny to communicate in emojis, itâ€™s not funny anymore to see emojis appearing as evidence. Because emojis are hard to interpret, they have caused a lot of evidentiary issues ğŸ˜±!

From XD to ğŸ˜‚

We shouldnâ€™t blame emojis for being hard to interpret, as emojis are designed to be so.

In our daily face-to-face conversations, we often make use of body language, facial expression, or acoustic tone to better convey our emotions. Yet such means becomes impossible when we move toward online conversations, in which we have access to plain text, i.e., 256 ASCII characters only. Scott Fahlman is probably one of the first to try imitating more diverse and emotional cues with plain text. He designed Emoticons to bridge the gap between verbal communications and digital conversations with only access to plain ASCII characters. Two of the most famous Emoticons are â€œ:-)â€ and â€œ:-( â€œ. While certain emoticons like â€œXDâ€ are easy to understand due to their resemblance to human faces, some of them seem more culturally orientated and hard to grasp by someone outside of the community. I probably would never guess the meaning of â€œ#â€‘)â€ If you are also wondering, it means "partied all night." . Of course, the never-satisfied Internet users demand more expressive symbols, leading to the development of the Emoticonâ€™s successor, the emoji.

Emojis are standardized collections of pictorial glyphs that are highly expressive. Originated in Japanese çµµæ–‡å­—, the name emoji itself precisely illustrates its pictographic nature: çµµ (e) being â€œpicture,â€ while æ–‡å­— (moji) being â€œcharacter.â€ Unchained from the 256 ASCII character limitation, emojis offer a virtually infinite array of expressions.

Emojis easily expand outside the territory of Emoticonâ€™s facial expression and extend to gesturesğŸ¤, fantasy ğŸ§šâ€â™€ï¸, clothing ğŸ‘˜, food ğŸ® or even slot machine ğŸ°. It is not hard to see that asides from being semantically richer, emojis are more colorful, vivid, intriguing, and expressive compared to Emoticon.

Equipped with such benefits, emojis gradually become an integral component in postmodern languages throughout the world. It is estimated that 92% of the online population use emoji, and at least 2.3 trillion mobile messages incorporate emoji annually as of 2016 . In 2021, Adobe released the global emoji trend report showing that 55% of global emoji users are more comfortable expressing emotions through emoji than through phone conversations, and 90% of global emoji users agree that emojis make it easier for them to express themselves. Therefore, it is not so surprising to see someone will exclaim something like this:

If ğŸ¤£ isnâ€™t your most frequent emoji used stay farrrrrrrr away from me

— kuz (@kylekuzma) June 22, 2022

Yet, emoticons and emojis serve similar functions: articulating and emphasizing the authorâ€™s intention. As I will illustrate below, emojis, similar to the natural language we have been using, are highly contextually and culturally bounded. As a result, they are subject to reinterpretation and/or misinterpretation.

Emojis obey distributional hypothesis ğŸ§

Weâ€™ll probably agree that natural languages have a lot of nuances, and it is difficult to tell the meaning of a word without knowing the full context. In the 1950s, a linguist John Rupert Firth propose the distributional hypothesis, meaning that the precise definition of a word is â€œcharacterized by the company it keeps.â€ As emojis are now playing an extensive role in communication, they more or less obey the distributional hypothesis, i.e., emojis are highly contextual. For example, ğŸ˜ can mean â€œitâ€™s cool,â€ â€œjob done,â€ and â€œsunny day it is,â€ to name a few.

I once wanted to research with a professor at USC and wrote a long email expressing my eagerness and competency. In the end, I wanted to â€œappeal to the pathos.â€ I hoped to implant a sense of emotional intimacy, making Professor harder to refuse my inquiry. â€œHey, we all belong to the Trojan family,â€ I thought. What can possibly be more idiomatic than the school slogan? I typed â€œFight onâœŒï¸!â€ at the end of the email. (by the way this is also the favorite emoji in USC!) Well, why append a âœŒï¸? Adobe report shows that 88% of the global emoji users are more likely to feel empathetic toward someone if they use an emoji. . Does it work? Well, I did get the opportunity, and in the email my Professor sent back, she concluded the email with â€œFight onâœŒï¸!â€

Let me do a quick dissection of what âœŒï¸ means. I am a USC student. USC Students tend to do a V sign when saying the USC slogan is â€œFight on.â€ I am writing to a professor at USC. You probably already see this: Trojanâ€™s slogan â€œFight Onâ€ is embedded in a simple emoji âœŒï¸. It is the context regarding USC that injects this particular meaning into âœŒï¸. For someone unaware of the whole context, âœŒï¸ would mean nothing more than a V sign.

The different implementations of emoji standards in various platforms add another layer of complexity. You might think you send a laughing ğŸ˜ emoji to convey a positive signal, but the receiver might think you are feeling embarrassed and awkward if the receiver happens to have an IPhone.

Emojis are cultural constructs ğŸ¤”

Donâ€™t you like emojis? Donâ€™t you think adding a cute emoji makes the conversation more friendly ğŸ™‚? Not if you are speaking to a Chinese. One time when I sent a meme to my American friend, he replied to me with â€œfunny ğŸ™‚.â€ Then as a Chinese, I began to question myself if I had done anything wrong to him since we Chinese only use smiling faces as a subtle indication to convey mock and despise.

As emojis reach millions of internet users throughout the globe, people from different regions develop different tastes in emoji usage. For example, asides from ğŸ™‚, clapping hands ğŸ‘ in China means something erotic, and in Brazil and Turkey ğŸ‘Œ is equivalent to a middle finger. Adobe report shows 63% of Gen Zâ€™ers mention that they use emojis differently than their intended meaning, with the most misunderstood emojis being ğŸ†Interestingly, Pornhub has released its own set of emojis, entitled "Emoji 4 Porn", with eggplant being one of them..

The cultural construct aspect of emojis is also being studied quantitatively. Researchers at Princeton and University College London have trained a neural network on English Tweeters and project a list of emojis into a 2D Cartesian plane . The visualization is shown in the left figure below. The closer two emojis are in the plane, the semantically closer the two emojis are. We can observe several clusters including a cluster of national flags, a cluster of digits, a cluster of laughing faces, etc. Yet such a pattern is not universal and probably only applicable to English, as found by Japanese researchers at the University of Tsukuba . They conduct similar experiments on Japanese social media and found a completely different patterns, such as different laughing emojis are not tightly close They use common emojis used by the Japanese, which is also significantly less than Americans..

Emoji projected into the 2D plane. Semantically similar emojis are mapped closer. The left figure is emoji used in English text, while the right is emoji used in Japanese text.

They credit the disparity in emoji semantic similarity to the difference in emoji culture. They found that for the same sentence Japanese sometimes react in a different emoji, as the table below shows. The Jp colomn is what a typical Jpanese will react for the given sentence, while En colomn is the response of a typical American.

The room where it happens âš–ï¸

Itâ€™s presumably fine that the interpretation of an emoji is conditioned on the person who sends the emoji, the cultural understanding of the emoji, and the context where emoji is used, because after all natural human language is no better. But in the courtroom, in which the precise meaning of each emoji needs to be rigorously scrutinized, emojis become a constant headache to judges due to their subtle sense that is hard to decipher. For example, if my coworker sends me a â¤ï¸, does it constitute sexual harassment? If my husband sends me a ğŸ”ª, does it imply a life threat?

Emojis invade courtroomsâ€¦ Itâ€™s a real thingâ—ï¸

Despite being relatively new, emojis have blossomed a millionfold with the advent of the computer era. Eventually, they also gained prominence in the courtroom. Recent years have witnessed a rise in cases involving emojis as evidence. According to Santa Clara Law professor Eric Goldman, back in 2004 there was only one case involving emojis, and the number went above 100 in 2019.

Judges are tasked to interpret the meaning of emojis to grasp the authorâ€™s intention behind those colorful pictograms. A final judgment will then be made based on their understanding of the emojis. The definition of emojis is however subjective. The existing emojipedia is far from satisfaction, as it provides explanations purely from the designerâ€™s perspective. Given the complexity of emojis as a social and cultural product, the judgments are often controversial. Sending a Chinese ğŸ™‚ would make the Chinese somewhat uncomfortable. This is a personal consequence of the complexity of emojis. What about legal consequences? What if you are fined or sent to the jail just because the understanding of some certain emojis are deviated?

Image yourself as a landlord; what will you think if you receive the following message from a prospective tenant:

â€œGood MorningğŸ˜Š Interested in the house ğŸ’ƒğŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸âœŒâ˜„ğŸ¿ï¸ğŸ¾ Whenâ€™s a good time for you?â€

A married couple Nir and Yarden sent precisely this to the landlord After reading this message and firmly believing that the couple had expressed a strong passion for the house, the landlord decided to take down the apartment listing from the market and send messages back to Nir and Yarden regarding the details of the housing contract. Yet the only response he got from the couple after a few days is that they instead rented another apartment.

Agitated, the landlord sued the couple for damages, claiming reliance â€”special contract law in Israel, that a party acting in reliance on anotherâ€™s expressed, and sometimes implied intent to agree to a deal may file suit if damaged when the other party doesnâ€™t follow through. How will you judge this case? The couple never explicitly confirmed that they would rent the house; they only asked to schedule a meeting with the landlord and had never signed any contract. However, the ruling by Judge Amir Weizebbluth is quite the opposite. He argued that this text message full of pictograms, smiling face ğŸ˜Š, dancing ğŸ’ƒğŸ‘¯â€â™€ï¸, and ChampagneğŸ¾ all convey â€œgreat optimism.â€ He further claimed that

Although this message did not constitute a binding contract between the parties, [it] naturally led to the Plaintiffâ€™s great reliance on the Defendantsâ€™ desire to rent his apartmentâ€¦

With the positive signal, the landlordâ€™s decision is understandable, if not perfectly reasonable based on the coupleâ€™s optimistic and colorful language. In the end, Nir and Yarden had to pay $2,200 for the bad faith negotiation. At first glance, this seems somewhat arbitrary that several emojis would cost two grand. I would rather consider those emojis a more approachable rhetorical technique, similar to what I have done when sending â€œFight onâœŒï¸!â€ to my Professor. None of those emojis are equivalent to the coupleâ€™s agreement for the contract. Besides, what does squirrel ğŸ¿ï¸ have to do with positive anyway? Due to the controversial outcome, this case became a classic in lawsuits that involve emojis, arousing debate on whether such complicated components as emojis can be used as convincing evidence.

In this case, it seems that It is not the emoji itself that judges look for, but how the employees perceive this (although deviating from the standard norm) that became the evidence judges utilized for the claim of insult. Rather inconsistent with the case of poor couple Nir and Yarden.

Do you think this will make a difference? The courtâ€™s decision is mainly based on the examination of emojis. They believe the content was â€œvaguely worded and peppered with smiling emojis.â€ In this case, if a judge completely omits the emoji, he probably will make a different judgment. Indeed, what if this text message is read or described by the lawyer to the judge?

Can we compile a list of evil emojis ğŸ˜ˆ?

Not all emojis are created equal. Some emojis are more likely to get you arrested. In 2016, there was a 12-year old that got arrested after posting on Instagram with ğŸ”«ğŸ”ªğŸ’£ emojis. However, this â€œmight get you arrestedâ€ list of emojis is not exhaustive. Even an innocuous and neutral emoji can be found threatening in a particular context.

For example, a judge sent a womanâ€™s ex-partner to jail for eight months for sending the following message to the womanâ€™s social media account:

Youâ€™re going to f***ing get it,âœˆ

Even though the aeroplane is considered harmless in most cases, in this scenario, both woman and the judge agree that this is a symbol of threat, suggesting that the ex-partner is coming to her. It seems we have left the situation puzzling about what those little pictograms mean when deriving from context. It is hard to gain a universal consensus about whether they indicate a sense of anger, humor, or other emotions, which probably is not what the inventor of emojis envisions emojis to be.
